title: Question 20
prompt: Who are the young girl and the old woman?
description:
Click the one best answer to each question.

The last two lines of the poem state:
In me she has drowned a young girl, and in me an old woman rises toward her day after day, like a terrible fish.
feedback: The poem depicts a woman looking into a mirror. In the mirror, the woman would see only herself. Day after day as she looks in the mirror, though, her face changes. When the poem states, “In me she had drowned a young girl,” it means that the face of the young girl has disappeared into the mirror. The woman is no longer young. As the woman loses her youth, she moves closer toward old age. She sees herself growing older in the mirror, as if an old woman is coming toward her. The old woman is herself when she is old: “in me an old woman rises toward her day after day, like a terrible fish.”
